Governor Brown will address the faculty on Thursday.  

Next Thursday, the high school faculty will meet.  

Simms reviewed the students’ leads and put them aside.  

He then informed them that they were all wrong.  

The lead to the story, he said, was, “There will be no school Thursday.”  

“In that instant,” Ephron recalls, “I realized that journalism was not just about regurgitating the facts but about figuring out the point.”  

It wasn’t enough to know the who, what, when, and where.  

You had to understand what it meant.  

And why it mattered.  

Ephron added, “He taught me something that works just as well in life as it does in journalism.”  

In every set of facts, something essential is hidden.  

A good journalist knows that finding it involves exploring those pieces of information.  

They figure out the relationships between them.  

My undergraduate degree was in journalism, so I take this seriously.  

It means making those relationships and connections explicit.  

It means constructing the whole from the sum of its parts.  

You must understand how these different pieces come together.  

They must matter to anyone.  

The best journalists do not simply relay information.  

Their value is in discovering what really matters to people.  

Have you ever felt lost and unsure about what to focus on?  

Have you ever felt overwhelmed by all of the information bombarding you?  

Have you ever felt dizzy from the different requests coming at you?  

Were you unable to figure out which are important and which are not?  

Have you ever missed the point to something in your work or at home?  

Did you not realize your mistake until it was too late?  

If so, this next Essentialist skill will be immensely valuable.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Good journalism involves uncovering the essential meaning behind facts, helping people focus on what truly matters amidst overwhelming information.
